text: The street-side medical stall smelled faintly of herbs. The white cloth curtain swayed gently in the breeze.
Alicia guided me to sit down. “Let them change your bandages properly.”
“That’s not necessary. I think it’s fine now.”
She raised an eyebrow. “You almost left your arm in that forest this morning.”
The apothecary brought clean bandages and a bowl of rinse water. Alicia took them herself, deftly unwrapping the old cloth and replacing it layer by layer.
“When you’re a mercenary, not knowing how to treat a wound is as good as signing your death warrant.”
Her tone was calm. The last strip of bandage was tied into a neat knot.
Her hand lingered on mine for a moment, as if checking that the pulse beneath the skin had steadied.
“Not anymore. Your hands work better than the medicine.”
She paused, then gave a small laugh. Sunlight slipped through the curtain, flickering over her eyelashes.
Then, she took my hand in hers.
For a moment, the noise of the marketplace faded, leaving only the warmth of her touch.
